The demand response (DR) program of a traditional home energy management system (HEMS) usually controls or schedules appliances to monitor energy usage, minimize energy cost, and maximize user comfort. In this study, instead of interfering with appliances and changing residents’ behavior, the proposed hour-ahead DR strategy first learns the appliance usage behavior of residents; subsequently, based on this knowledge, it silently controls the energy storage system (ESS) and renewable energy system (RES) to minimize the daily energy cost. To accomplish the goal, the proposed deep neural networks (DNNs) of this DR approximate the MILP optimization using supervised learning. The training datasets are created from the optimal outputs of an MILP solver using historical data. After training, in each time slot, these DNNs are used to control the ESS and RES using the real-time data of the surrounding environment. For comparison, we develop two different strategies, namely, the multi-agent reinforcement learning-based strategy, which is an hour-ahead strategy, and the forecast-based MILP strategy, which is a day-ahead strategy. For evaluation and verification, the proposed approaches are applied to three different real-world homes with real-world real-time global horizontal irradiation and prices. Numerical results verify the effectiveness and superiority of the proposed MILP-based supervised learning strategy, in terms of the daily energy cost. t ) Variable dependent on E R E S l o a d ( t ) and E E S S C D ( t ) R L ( t ) Variable dependent on E E C ( t ) and E R E S ( t ) 1 Introduction With the remarkable development of renewable energy systems (RESs) and energy storage systems (ESSs), the importance of a home energy management system (HEMS) for helping residents reduce their energy consumption is growing. Building an HEMS with an optimal demand response (DR) that modifies a resident’s electric usage in response to changes in the electricity price and surrounding environment [1] has received significant attention from researchers. Nowadays, with the notable developments in machine learning, and specifically deep learning techniques, many intelligent strategies for DR programs that adapt to real-time environmental changes have been proposed. In many previous studies (e.g. [2–4]), appliances were generally divided into two categories: non-shiftable and shiftable devices. For shiftable devices, residents first set up appropriate time slots for the devices to be run. An HEMS with a DR program then attempted to identify an optimal day-ahead schedule for shiftable devices, satisfying all the constraints of the appliances, and achieving multiple objectives. To determine such a schedule, an explicit optimization model was built and solved. For example, in [5], an optimization model for minimizing the energy cost was built, and the particle swarm optimization (PSO) algorithm was used to solve this model and determine an optimal day-head schedule. In [6], an optimization model that minimized both, the energy cost and peak-to-average (PAR) ratio, was built, and a day-ahead schedule for appliances was determined using a genetic algorithm. In [7], the authors proposed an optimization model in which the sales of energy were supported and a day-ahead schedule of appliances and selling operation was determined by a PSO algorithm. Besides heuristic methods, mathematical solvers are often used to solve explicit optimization models. The authors of [8] built a mixed-integer linear programming (MILP) model to minimize the energy cost and used a CPLEX solver to establish a day-ahead schedule for appliances. In [9], a mixed-integer nonlinear programming (MINLP) solver was used to solve a multi-objective optimization model that minimized the energy cost and maximized user comfort. Likewise, in [10], a multi-objective MINLP model that jointly optimized four objectives (energy cost, user comfort, PAR, and waiting time) was built and solved by CPLEX/CONOPT solvers. In these aforementioned studies, constructing explicit optimization models required detailed domain knowledge and day-ahead forecast data such as the day-ahead outdoor temperature. These forecast data inevitably contained errors that degraded the performance of the DR. To overcome these challenges, learning-based approaches were introduced. For example, in [11], three hidden Markov models (HMMs) were built to learn the probability of each living activity and operational time of appliances. In these models, an agent assessed the running requests of appliances based on consumption constraints, convenience, and grid signals. Based on actor–critic reinforcement learning (RL), the authors of [12] developed an online load-scheduling learning algorithm with real-time pricing for optimal scheduling of the controllable appliances. A multi-agent (MA) Q-learning algorithm was adopted in [13,14], where the on–off operations and discrete power inputs of appliances were considered. The agents representing all the appliances were coordinated to minimize the electricity and dissatisfaction costs. Although RL agents do not require prior knowledge, their applicability is usually limited to domains with fully observable, low-dimensional state spaces because of their instability or divergence [15]. Deep RL (DRL) techniques, in which a deep neural network (DNN) is used to approximate an action-value function of complex, high-dimensional state spaces, have been exploited in many hour-ahead residential DRs. For instance, the authors of [16] proposed a deep Q-learning network (DQN)-based algorithm that optimized the energy consumption of heating, ventilation, and air conditioning (HVAC) and maintained thermal comfort and air quality at the given levels. In [17], the DQN and Deep Policy Gradient (DPG) methods were used to schedule the energy of electric vehicles and buildings appliances online. In [18], a deep deterministic policy gradient (DDPG) algorithm was adopted to schedule the ESS and HVAC to minimize the energy cost and provide a satisfactory and comfortable temperature range in a smart home. To schedule discretely and continuously controlled appliances in real-time, in [19], the trust region policy optimization (TRPO)-based algorithm, a type of DRL algorithm, was proposed based on the real-time electricity price and outdoor temperature. DRL techniques have achieved significant success in the abovementioned hour-ahead DR programs. However, for some problems, common DRL approaches sometimes are unstable or difficult to converge [20]. Imitation learning (IL) has been employed to solve such problems in some studies. For example, in [21,22], the authors proposed optimal DRs that first learn a mapping (or a policy) between the optimal actions of an MILP solver and historical states of the environment for HVAC systems; subsequently, the knowledge is deployed to schedule the systems using real-time environmental data. In other words, the DRs attempt to approximate MILP optimization. The DNNs of these DRs were trained using the supervised learning technique. Their simulations proved that the IL-based method outperformed the DDPG-based method. In [23], an IL-based online power scheduling was developed to manage the energy of a micro-grid in real time. In this study, the MINLP problem was first simplified via piece-wise linear approximation and transformed into an MILP problem. Subsequently, a DNN was trained to approximate MILP optimization using data-labeled optimal outputs of the MILP solver with historical data. In online scheduling, this DNN was used to control the device in each time slot. The proposed IL-based approach outperformed the proximal policy optimization (PPO)-based approach. In these aforementioned studies, the DR generally intervened in the operation of appliances and modified the appliance usage behavior of residents. In this study, we propose a supervised-learning based strategy for an HEMS with an hour-ahead DR that learns resident behavior and controls the ESS and RES unobtrusively to minimize the daily energy cost based on the knowledge. Thus, residents can maintain their typical appliance usage behavior and enjoy maximum comfort. The DR imitates the behaviors of an MILP solver to achieve hour-ahead control of the ESS and RES. First, the DNNs of the DR are trained to learn an MILP optimization approximation using the supervised learning technique, a traditional approach of the IL. The training datasets used are labeled by optimal actions created by an MILP solver using historical data. After training, these DNNs are then used to control the ESS and RES using the current real-time data in each time slot. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first study that addresses ESS and RES control by applying the knowledge of behavior of residents and MILP optimization approximation in a HEMS. Moreover, our proposed strategy, a kind of hour-ahead strategies, can deal with the uncertainty of both renewable energy and real-time prices of the energy market. The main contributions of our study are as follows: • We build two versions of a daily energy cost minimization problem based on the hourly energy consumption of residents for the DR of an HEMS integrating ESS, RES, and sales operations. In these versions, the appliance usage behavior of residents could be used to optimize the DR. • Based on these formulas, we propose three strategies: MILP-based supervised learning, multi-agent deep deterministic policy gradient (MADDPG), and forecast-based MILP. The first two strategies are hour-ahead strategies and the last is a day-ahead strategy. • Three extensive case studies based on real-world real-time data are performed to evaluate the strategies. Numerical results demonstrate that the MILP-based supervised learning strategy is the most effective, in terms of the daily energy cost, when residents have a good appliance usage behavior. The rest of this paper is organized as follows. The problem is formulated in Section 2. The details of the three strategies are described in Section 3. Case studies and simulation results are provided in Section 4. Some ideas are discussed in Section 5. Finally, the conclusion and future works are outlined in Section 6. 2 System model and problem formulation The components of a smart home considered in this study are shown in Fig. 1, where an ESS and a PV system as RES are represented. The electricity provider can be any company that sells electricity to homes. The main goals of using the ESS and the PV system are to reduce the energy demand from the electricity provider and enable residents to sell excess energy to increase their benefit. In the discharging mode, our ESS is functioned as an energy source that supplies energy to appliances and sells excess energy to other homes. On the other hand, in the charging mode, our ESS could store RES energy and inexpensive energy from the electricity provider for future use. Our RES energy could be used for appliances and stored in the ESS. Subsequently, the ESS and RES models are provided, following which a daily energy cost minimization problem is built for a day. We also divide a day into T = 24 time slots. The duration of each is Δ t = 1 h . 2.1 ESS model Let E E S S L e v e l ( t ) be the energy level of the ESS after time slot t . As described in Fig. 1, with ∀ t , 1 ≤ t ≤ T , we obtain the following formula: (1) E E S S L e v e l ( t ) = E E S S L e v e l ( t − 1 ) + ( E R E S c h a r g e ( t ) + E E P c h a r g e ( t ) ) ⋅ η E S S − ( E E S S l o a d ( t ) + E E S S s e l l ( t ) ) / η E S S where E E S S l o a d ( t ) ≥ 0 is an energy quantity used for appliances at time slot t . E E S S s e l l ( t ) ≥ 0 is an energy quantity used to make sales at time slot t . E R E S c h a r g e ( t ) ≥ 0 is an energy quantity stored in the ESS from the RES at time slot t . E E P c h a r g e ( t ) ≥ 0 is an energy quantity stored in the ESS from the electricity provider at time slot t . η E S S is the ESS efficiency. When using the ESS, the following constraints must be satisfied. (2) E L m i n ≤ E E S S L e v e l ( t ) ≤ E L m a x (3) E R E S c h a r g e ( t ) + E E P c h a r g e ( t ) ≤ C h r a t e ⋅ Δ t ⋅ m o d e E S S ( t ) (4) E E S S l o a d ( t ) + E E S S s e l l ( t ) ≤ D h r a t e ⋅ Δ t ⋅ ( 1 − m o d e E S S ( t ) ) (5) m o d e E S S ( t ) = 1 if ESS is charged in time slot t 0 if ESS is discharged in time slot t where E L m i n and E L m a x are the minimum and maximum energy levels of the ESS, respectively. C h r a t e and D h r a t e are the maximum charge and discharge rates of the ESS, respectively. m o d e E S S ( t ) is a binary variable to prevent the ESS from charging and discharging simultaneously at time slot t . It is assumed that the ESS could not charge and discharge simultaneously. We only consider our system during a day (no net accumulation for next day); here, the energy level should be returned to the initial value, E L 0 , at the end of the day. Thus, we have (6) E E S S L e v e l ( T ) = E L 0 . 2.2 RES model According to [24,25], the output energy E R E S ( t ) from a PV system in kWh in any time slot t ( 1 ≤ t ≤ T ) can be measured as follows: (7) E R E S ( t ) = G H I r e a l t i m e ( t ) ⋅ S ⋅ η R E S ⋅ Δ t . where G H I r e a l t i m e ( t ) is the real-time global horizontal irradiation ( kW / m 2 ) at the location of the solar panels in time slot t . S is the total area ( m 2 ) of the solar panels and η R E S is the solar conversion efficiency of the PV system. As shown in Fig. 1, the energy can be used for appliances and ESS charging. Thus, we have the following constraint. (8) E R E S l o a d ( t ) + E R E S c h a r g e ( t ) ≤ E R E S ( t ) where E R E S l o a d ( t ) ≥ 0 is an energy quantity used for appliances at time slot t . It is worth noting that if ESS is in discharging mode, the RES energy is only used for appliances. In this mode, we have E R E S c h a r g e ( t ) = 0 and E R E S l o a d ( t ) = E E C ( t ) where E E C ( t ) is the energy consumption of all the appliances at time slot t . The proposed HEMS attempts to utilize the RES energy to a maximum degree. However, the RES energy can be lost or wasted when the RES energy exceeds the total energy demand of all the appliances if ESS is in discharging mode or the RES energy exceeds the sum of E R E S l o a d ( t ) and E R E S c h a r g e ( t ) if ESS is in charging mode. In detail, the loss of RES energy can be calculated as (9) E R E S l o s s ( t ) = E R E S ( t ) − ( E R E S l o a d ( t ) + E R E S c h a r g e ( t ) ) if ESS is charged in time slot t m a x { E R E S ( t ) − E E C ( t ) , 0 } if ESS is discharged in time slot t 2.3 Energy balancing To maintain the energy balance in a smart home, the total energy demand and supply should be equal. Hence, as shown in Fig. 1, with ∀ t , 1 ≤ t ≤ T , we have (10) E E C ( t ) = E E P l o a d ( t ) + E E S S l o a d ( t ) + E R E S l o a d ( t ) . where E E C ( t ) ≥ 0 is the energy consumption of all the appliances at time slot t . E E P l o a d ( t ) ≥ 0 is the energy quantity used for the appliances from the electricity provider at time slot t . 2.4 Daily energy cost minimization problem We assume that the energy from the RES and ESS is complementary and that the real-time selling P s e l l ( t ) and buying prices P r e a l t i m e ( t ) are related (e.g., P s e l l ( t ) = α p ⋅ P r e a l t i m e ( t ) with α p as a constant and α p ≤ 1 ). Subsequently, the daily energy cost minimization problem could be formulated as (11) m i n ∑ t = 1 T C ( t ) = m i n ∑ t = 1 T ( ( E E P l o a d ( t ) + E E P c h a r g e ( t ) ) ⋅ P r e a l t i m e ( t ) − E E S S s e l l ( t ) ⋅ α p ⋅ P r e a l t i m e ( t ) ) Combining with (10), the problem in (11) could be converted into (12) m i n ∑ t = 1 T C ( t ) = m i n ∑ t = 1 T ( E E C ( t ) − E R E S l o a d ( t ) + E E P c h a r g e ( t ) − E E S S l o a d ( t ) − α p ⋅ E E S S s e l l ( t ) ) ⋅ P r e a l t i m e ( t ) s . t . (1)–(8) It is clear that when the energy consumption E E C ( t ) and real-time irradiation G H I r e a l t i m e ( t ) and real-time buying price P r e a l t i m e ( t ) at every time slot t of a day are known, the problem (12) is an MILP problem. Hence, using MILP solvers, we easily determine the optimal values of the variables E R E S l o a d ( t ) , E E P c h a r g e ( t ) , E E S S l o a d ( t ) , and E E S S s e l l ( t ) at every time slot t . These optimal values are the optimal energies of the ESS and RES that should be used at each time slot to optimize the daily energy cost. Unfortunately, this information is only available at the end of the day. Therefore, MILP solvers are only useful at the end of the day when it is too late to control them. Hence, to overcome this problem and utilize the powerful MILP solvers, we propose MILP-based supervised learning strategies in the next section. 2.5 Different version of daily energy cost minimization problem Because the ESS cannot be charged and discharged simultaneously in a time slot, we define a new float variable E E S S C D ( t ) that refers to an energy quantity stored in the ESS at time slot t , if E E S S C D ( t ) ≥ 0 , and refers to an energy quantity drawn from the ESS at time slot t , if E E S S C D ( t ) < 0 . Therefore, (13) E E S S C D ( t ) = E R E S c h a r g e ( t ) + E E P c h a r g e ( t ) E E S S C D ( t ) ≥ 0 − ( E E S S l o a d ( t ) + E E S S s e l l ( t ) ) E E S S C D ( t ) < 0 Hence, we have the following constraint for E E S S C D ( t ) . (14) − D h r a t e ⋅ Δ t ≤ E E S S C D ( t ) ≤ C h r a t e ⋅ Δ t With the definition of E E S S C D ( t ) as in (13), E E S S l e v e l ( t ) can be calculated as follows. (15) E E S S l e v e l ( t ) = E E S S l e v e l ( t − 1 ) + E E S S C D ( t ) ⋅ η E S S E E S S C D ( t ) ≥ 0 E E S S l e v e l ( t − 1 ) + E E S S C D ( t ) / η E S S E E S S C D ( t ) < 0 When the ESS is in the charge mode ( E E S S C D ( t ) ≥ 0 ) in time slot t , E E S S l o a d ( t ) = E E S S s e l l ( t ) = 0 . Combined with (13), the energy cost of the home in this time slot can be calculated as follows. (16) C ( t ) = ( E E C ( t ) − E R E S l o a d ( t ) + E E S S C D ( t ) − E R E S c h a r g e ( t ) ) ⋅ P r e a l t i m e ( t ) (17) ⇒ C ( t ) = ( E E C ( t ) − E R E S l o a d ( t ) + E E S S C D ( t ) − R C ( t ) ) ⋅ P r e a l t i m e ( t ) where variable R C ( t ) , which depends on E R E S l o a d ( t ) and E E S S C D ( t ) , is calculated as (18) R C ( t ) = m i n { E R E S ( t ) − E R E S l o a d ( t ) , E E S S C D ( t ) } . When the ESS is in the discharge mode ( E E S S C D ( t ) < 0 ) in a time slot t , E R E S c h a r g e ( t ) = E E P c h a r g e ( t ) = 0 . Hence, the energy cost in this time slot can be calculated as follows. (19) C ( t ) = E E P l o a d ( t ) ⋅ P r e a l t i m e ( t ) − E E S S s e l l ( t ) ⋅ α p ⋅ P r e a l t i m e ( t ) Because P s e l l ( t ) ≤ P r e a l t i m e ( t ) , we only sell energy when the total energy supply exceeded the energy consumption of all the appliances in the time slot. Hence, (20) C ( t ) = ( E E C ( t ) − E R E S l o a d ( t ) + E E S S C D ( t ) ) ⋅ P r e a l t i m e ( t ) if E E C ( t ) ≥ E R E S l o a d ( t ) − E E S S C D ( t ) ( E E C ( t ) − E R E S l o a d ( t ) + E E S S C D ( t ) ) ⋅ α p ⋅ P r e a l t i m e ( t ) if E E C ( t ) < E R E S l o a d ( t ) − E E S S C D ( t ) It is worth noting that in the discharge mode, all the RES energy is used for only appliances. Let R L ( t ) = m a x { E E C ( t ) − E R E S ( t ) , 0 } , we have (21) C ( t ) = ( R L ( t ) + E E S S C D ( t ) ) ⋅ P r e a l t i m e ( t ) if R L ( t ) ≥ − E E S S C D ( t ) ( R L ( t ) + E E S S C D ( t ) ) ⋅ α p ⋅ P r e a l t i m e ( t ) if R L ( t ) < − E E S S C D ( t ) In summary, the daily energy cost minimization problem could be formulated as follows. (22) m i n ∑ t = 1 T C ( t ) s . t . (2), (6), (7), (8), (14), (15), (18) where C ( t ) is calculated as in (17) if E E S S C D ≥ 0 and is calculated as in (21) if E E S S C D < 0 . Although this version of our minimization problem is not an MILP problem, it depends solely on two variables: E E S S C D ( t ) and E R E S l o a d ( t ) . To solve this version, we propose a multi-agent DRL-based strategy in which an agent controls E E S S C D ( t ) of the ESS and another agent controls E R E S l o a d ( t ) of the RES to minimize the daily energy cost. 3 Three optimal strategies To solve our problem and deal with the uncertainty of both renewable energy and real-time price, MILP-based supervised learning strategy, a kind of hour-ahead strategies, is proposed. Avoiding using forecast data of the environment, at the beginning of each time slot, our proposed strategy only uses current real-time values of both GHI and price to determine the amount of RES energy generated by PV systems and control ESS and RES appropriately in this time slot. For comparison, we also implement other strategies: MADDPG-based strategy and forecast-based MILP strategy. The MADDPG-based strategy is a kind of DRL algorithms which are usually used for the real-time (or hour-ahead) control of appliances and energy resources of HEMS in many previous studies [18,26]. The forecast-based MILP strategy is deployed from classical day-ahead strategies [9,10]. In this day-ahead strategy, ESS and RES are controlled by a day-ahead schedule created by a mathematical solver (or a heuristic algorithm) with 24 -hour forecast data of the environment. 3.1 MILP-based supervised learning strategy In the MILP-based supervised learning strategy, at the beginning, the problem in (12) is solved using an MILP solver with the necessary environmental data of previous days. The results of the process are the optimal values of the variables of the ESS and RES required for control at each time slot of these historical days. From these optimal values, the datasets for these variables are built and used to train the DNNs that subsequently learns an approximation of an MILP solver. After training, the DNNs are used to control them in each time slot using the current real-time data. However, these DNNs also require the forecast value of the energy consumption of all the appliances in each time slot as their input data. Hence, the proposed HEMS must learn the appliance usage behavior of residents to predict the energy consumption for the next 1 time slot. Fig. 2 shows the overall framework of the MILP-based supervised learning in detail. In Step 1 , the historical energy consumption E E C h i s [ 1 : 24 ] , the irradiation G H I h i s [ 1 : 24 ] , and prices P h i s [ 1 : 24 ] of a historical day are the input data for the MILP solver. The outputs are the optimal energy required to control the ESS and RES at 24 time slots of the historical day: E ˜ R E S l o a d [ 1 : 24 ] , E ˜ E P c h a r g e [ 1 : 24 ] , E ˜ E S S l o a d [ 1 : 24 ] , E ˜ E S S s e l l [ 1 : 24 ] . The MILP solver also provides optimal energy levels E ˜ E S S L e v e l [ 1 : 24 ] for the ESS after 24 time slots of this day. A training dataset D E R E S l o a d for the variable E R E S l o a d ( t ) is then structured using the following format: i n p u t = [ E E C h i s [ t ] , G H I h i s [ t ] , E ˜ E S S L e v e l [ t − 1 ] , P h i s [ t ] , t ] l a b e l = [ E ˜ R E S l o a d [ t ] ] By changing the content of the label into E ˜ E P c h a r g e [ t ] , we obtain a new training dataset D E E P c h a r g e for variable E E P c h a r g e ( t ) . In a similar way, we obtain new training datasets D E E S S l o a d and D E E S S s e l l for variables E E S S l o a d ( t ) and E E S S s e l l ( t ) respectively. In Step 2 , four datasets D E R E S l o a d , D E E P c h a r g e , D E E S S l o a d , and D E E S S s e l l are used to train the four neural networks D N N E R E S l o a d , D N N E E P c h a r g e , D N N E E S S l o a d , and D N N E E S S s e l l of the proposed DR, respectively. It is worth noting that in Fig. 2, only D N N E R E S l o a d is shown. It is also necessary to train a recurrent neural network (RNN) to predict the amount of energy consumption of the home in the next 1 time slot. In this study, we use an RNN with gated recurrent unit (GRU) cells, R N N E C , that is composed of 2 layers and had a time step of 168 . Finally, in Step 3 , the proposed DR uses four trained DNNs and R N N E C to control the ESS and RES in 1 time slot. At the beginning of each time slot t in a day, the R N N E C is first used to compute the forecast value E ̆ E C [ t ] of the energy consumption E E C ( t ) in the time slot. Subsequently, [ E ̆ E C [ t ] , G H I r e a l t i m e [ t ] , E E S S L e v e l [ t − 1 ] , P r e a l t i m e [ t ] , t ] are defined as the input data for D N N E R E S l o a d , and the output is the forecast value E ̆ R E S l o a d [ t ] of the variable E R E S l o a d ( t ) . Similarly, these input data are also used as the input data for the remaining DNNs, and the forecast values of the other variables are achieved. After obtaining the forecast values of four variables, they are used to control the ESS and RES in this time slot. It is worth noting that, in this step, all the input data are current real-time values, except for E ̆ E C [ t ] . Evidently, the efficiency of the strategy is determined by the accuracy of the energy consumption prediction in the next 1 time slot (the performance of R N N E C ) that is described in Section 4. More details on the MILP-based supervised learning strategy can be found in Algorithm 1. 3.2 MADDPG-based strategy The minimization problem defined in (22) can be solved using advanced MA-DRL algorithms. The key components of the MA-DRL environment can be described as follows. (1) State: The environment state s t includes 5 kinds of information at the beginning of each time slot t : the energy consumption E E C [ t ] , real-time irradiation G H I r e a l t i m e [ t ] , current energy level of ESS E E S S L e v e l [ t − 1 ] , real-time price P r e a l t i m e [ t ] , and time slot t . For brevity, we denoted the state by s t = [ E E C [ t ] , G H I r e a l t i m e [ t ] , E E S S L e v e l [ t − 1 ] , P r e a l t i m e [ t ] , t ] . (2) Agents and actions: The proposed DR is composed of two agents A E S S and A R E S whose goals are to determine the optimal values of variables E E S S C D ( t ) and E R E S l o a d ( t ) that should be used to control the ESS and RES in time slot t , respectively. Hence, the action of A E S S is defined as a E S S [ t ] = E E S S C D [ t ] whereas the action of A R E S is defined as a R E S [ t ] = E R E S l o a d [ t ] . (3) Reward: At the beginning of each time slot t , when two agents execute their actions, the transition of the environment state from s t to s t + 1 is triggered and the two agents receive the same reward R t . Our objective is to minimize the daily energy cost. Hence, R t is defined as R t = − C ( t ) , with C ( t ) calculated as in (17), if a E S S [ t ] ≥ 0 , and calculated as in (21), if a E S S [ t ] < 0 . Because the action space of both agents is continuous, we propose a strategy based on the MADDPG algorithm [27] whose architecture is shown in Fig. 3. The MADDPG algorithm, an extended version of the DDPG algorithm [29], is applied to an MA environment and defeated other DRL algorithms such as DQN, Actor–Critic, and TRPO [27]. In detail, considering a game with N agents, with 1 ≤ i ≤ N , each agent has an actor network (or policy network) and a critic network (or Q-network) defined as μ i ( o i | θ i μ ) and Q i ( s , a | θ i Q ) where o i , θ i μ are the local observation (local state) and the weights of the actor network of agent i . s = ( o 1 , … , o N ) and a = ( a 1 , … , a N ) are the joint observations (global state) and joint actions of all agents. θ i Q is the weights of the critic network of agent i . Clearly, Q i ( s , a | θ i Q ) is a centralized Q-network. Each agent needs to collect information from other agents for training its own Q-network. The main idea of MADDPG algorithm is to allow each agent to build a centralized Q-network and derive a decentralized actor network using this critic network. The training process of the MADDPG algorithm can be described shortly as follows. At the first step, each agent selects and executes an action a i = μ i ( o i | θ i μ ) + N t where N t is the random process for action exploration. It then observes reward r i and new local observation o i ′ . The joint actions a = ( a 1 , … , a N ) , new joint observations s ′ = ( o 1 ′ , … , o N ′ ) , and joint rewards r = ( r 1 , … , r N ) are collected and a set of data ( s , a , r , s ′ ) is stored in replay buffer D . With a random mini-batch of K samples ( s k , a k , r k , s ′ k ) , the critic network of each agent is updated by minimizing the loss: (23) L i ( θ i Q ) = 1 K ∑ k ( Q i ( s k , a k | θ i Q ) − y i k ) 2 with (24) y i k = r i k + γ Q i ′ ( s ′ k , a ′ | θ i Q ′ ) | a i ′ = μ i ′ ( o i ′ | θ i μ ′ ) where Q i ′ ( s , a | θ i Q ′ ) , μ i ′ ( o i | θ i μ ′ ) are the critic target network and the actor target network of agent i , respectively. The actor network of each agent is also updated by using the sampled policy gradient: (25) ∇ θ i μ J ( θ i μ ) ≈ 1 K ∑ k ∇ θ i μ μ i ( o i k | θ i μ ) ∇ a i Q i ( s k , a k | θ i Q ) | a i = μ i ( o i | θ i μ ) By iteratively running this training process, the MADDPG algorithm can eventually produce the optimal actor and critic network for each agent. It should be noticed that, the centralized critic network Q i ( s , a | θ i Q ) is only used during learning. In real-time application, we only need the actor network μ i ( o i | θ i μ ) which only requires a local observation to generate an action. The detailed MADDPG algorithm can be found in Algorithm 3. Our optimization problem in (12) is to minimize the energy cost for a day and the best energy cost of the day is calculated by a MILP solver at the end of the day when full information of environment is already known. These MILP results can be identified as the benchmark for evaluating the performance of the MADDPG algorithm during training process. Because these MILP results of the days in the training dataset are very different and have a wide range, we use a new metric for evaluation: r e a l − g a p = c o s t M A D D P G − c o s t M I L P where c o s t M A D D P G is the energy cost of a real day outputted by the MADDPG algorithm and c o s t M I L P is the best energy cost of this day calculated by the MILP solver. Fig. 4 shows the learning curve of MADDPG algorithm during the training process in our problem. As depicted in this figure, at the initial stages when two agents have the limited knowledge on how to select actions and are randomly exploring action space, the values of r e a l − g a p are very high. It means that the daily energy cost outputted by the MADDPG algorithm is larger a lot than the best energy cost calculated by the MILP solver and the performance of the MADDPG algorithm is poor. However, as episodes are passed, the values of r e a l − g a p are gradually smaller. It means that the daily energy cost outputted by the MADDPG algorithm gets more and more close to the best energy cost and the performance of the MADDPG algorithm is gradually improved. To show the changing trend of r e a l − g a p more clearly, we also provide the average gap which is the average of the latest 50 values of r e a l − g a p in Fig. 4. It is found that, at the beginning, the average gap is high; however, it gradually decreases and becomes more and more stable. The proposed MADDPG-based strategy of the DR can be described as follows. In Step 1 , the agents A E S S and A R E S are trained using the historical energy consumption E E C h i s [ 1 : 24 ] , historical irradiation G H I h i s [ 1 : 24 ] , and historical prices P h i s [ 1 : 24 ] . Similar to the supervised learning strategy, an RNN R N N E C is also trained to predict the energy consumption of the home in the next 1 time slot. After training all the agents, in Step 2 , at the beginning of each time slot t of a day, the R N N E C is first used to compute the forecast value E ̆ E C [ t ] of the energy consumption E E C ( t ) in the time slot. Subsequently, [ E ̆ E C [ t ] , G H I r e a l t i m e [ t ] , E E S S L e v e l [ t − 1 ] , P r e a l t i m e [ t ] , t ] are used as the input data for the actor networks of two agents A E S S and A R E S . The outputs are the forecast values of variables E E S S C D ( t ) and E R E S l o a d ( t ) that should be used to control the ESS and RES in this time slot. The detailed MADDPG-based strategy is presented in Algorithm 3. 3.3 Forecast-based MILP strategy The main prerequisite to using the MILP solver is that all the values of the energy consumption E E C ( t ) , real-time irradiation G H I r e a l t i m e ( t ) , and real-time price P r e a l t i m e ( t ) must be known at every time slot of the day. However, this information is usually not available until the end of the day. Hence, we propose a forecast-based MILP strategy whereby all the data required by the MILP solver are forecast at the beginning of the day. The strategy may be briefly explained as follows. In Step 1 , the RNNs for predicting the energy consumption, real-time irradiation, and real-time prices for the next 24 time slots are trained. In Step 2 , at the beginning of a day, we obtain the forecast values of the energy consumption, real-time irradiation, and real-time prices for 24 time slots in a day using these RNNs. Subsequently, the forecast values are used to solve (12) using an MILP solver. The outputs of the MILP solver are the forecast values of all the variables of the ESS and RES that will be used to control the ESS and RES in each time slot during the day. The detailed forecast-based MILP strategy is clarified in Algorithm 4. 4 Case studies and simulation results In this section, we describe the simulation setup and different case studies to which the proposed strategies are applied. The performances of the proposed strategies are evaluated through the numerical simulation results obtained for these case studies. For comparison, the efficiencies of the proposed strategies are first calculated based on the MILP results that are achieved only at the end of a day when the full information of the day is already known. From these results, the performances of the proposed strategies are compared. 4.1 Simulation setup The performances of the proposed strategies are evaluated based on the accuracy of the energy consumption prediction in the next 1 time slot. In other words, the performances of the strategies depend on the appliance usage behaviors of the residents. Hence, for evaluation and comparison, the proposed strategies are applied to three different real-world homes in London, UK that are classified based on residents’ behavior: s t a b l e , f l u c t u a t i n g , and c h a o t i c . The datasets of these homes are extracted from the “Energy Consumption Data in London Households” dataset, the largest real-world dataset of the UK Power Network from Jan 2012 to Feb 2014 [30]. In stable homes, the resident appliance usage behavior is almost constant every day. Fig. 5 shows the historical dataset for the hourly energy consumption of such a home. After training the R N N E C using this dataset, the one-hour-forecast value predicted by the R N N E C is almost the same as the actual value in the testing set. The average MAPE of the testing set is only 0.6%. The fluctuating home is one in which the resident usage behavior varies slightly. Fig. 6 shows the historical dataset of the hourly energy consumption of this home. After training the R N N E C using this dataset, the one-hour-forecast value predicted by the R N N E C is slightly different from the actual value in the testing set. The average MAPE of the testing set is 10.9%. The chaotic home is one in which the resident usage behavior is unstable. Fig. 7 shows the historical dataset for the hourly energy consumption of this home. After training the R N N E C using this dataset, the one-hour-forecast value predicted by the R N N E C is very different from the real value in the testing set. The average MAPE of the testing set is 21.8%. In our simulations, the real-time hourly solar irradiation on London, UK from Jan 2012 to Feb 2014 shown in Fig. 8 is extracted from the database of the “Photovoltaic Geographical Information System” of the European Commission [31]. For the real-time hourly prices, because we does not know the real-time prices of electricity in London, the real-time hourly prices of Michigan from Jan 2016 to Feb 2018 obtained from the Pecan Street database [32] are used, as shown in Fig. 9. Specifically, in all the above datasets, the data from Jan 2012 to Jan 2014 are used to train the neural networks of the proposed strategies and the data of Feb 2014 are used to test and evaluate the performance of the proposed strategies. We set the dataset size to two years since the two-year dataset showed the best performance among the various dataset sizes as shown in Fig. 10. The main parameters of the ESS, RES, and MADDPG algorithm are listed in Table 1. N R E S a , N R E S c , N E S S a , and N E S S c are the configuration parameters of the actor and the critic network of the RES and ESS agents, respectively. Specifically, the actor network of the RES agent has 2 hidden layers and each layer has 100 neurons. The actor network of the ESS agent has 3 layers and each layer has 200 neurons. The critic networks of the RES agent and the ESS agent have the same configuration. They have 3 hidden layers where the first layer has 100 neurons and each layer of last two layers has 200 neurons. l r a , and l r c are the learning rate of the actor network and critic network, respectively. Our simulations are run on Intel(R) Core(TM) i7-8700 CPU @ 3.20 GHz (12 CPUs) and 16 GB RAM with NVIDIA GeForceGTX 1060 6 GB and Windows 10 pro installed. 4.2 Performance evaluation and comparison of three strategies Fig. 11 shows the energy cost achieved by the three strategies for each day in February 2014 (testing set) for a stable home. The black line is the daily energy cost without the ESS and RES and the red line is the optimal daily energy cost that could be achieved using the MILP solver at the end of each day when the ESS and RES are maximally utilized and the full information of that day is already known. These MILP results (red line) represented the best daily energy costs we can achieve, and this line is a lower bound of the proposed strategies. As shown in this figure, of the three strategies, the daily energy costs achieved by the MILP-based supervised learning and forecast-based strategies are the closest and farthest from the red line, respectively, indicating the best and worst performances, respectively. Similarly, for the fluctuating home and chaotic home, the daily energy cost of the MILP-based supervised learning strategy is the closest to the red line, as shown in Figs. 12 and 13, respectively. Hence, it also is the best among the three strategies, while the forecast-based strategy is the worst for these homes. As has been established thus far, one of the main objectives of using the ESS and RES is to reduce the daily energy cost to the greatest extent; to this end, optimal cost-saving is achieved by the MILP solver. For better comparison among the strategies, we introduce a new metric, as shown in (26), to determine the effectiveness of each proposed strategy on the testing set. The metric demonstrates the percentage average cost saved by each strategy compared with the MILP solver. (26) E f f M I L P s t r a t e g y = ∑ i = 1 N C b a s e i − C s t r a t e g y i C b a s e i ∑ i = 1 N C b a s e i − C M I L P i C b a s e i × 100 where N is the number of days in the testing set. C b a s e i is the energy cost of the day i without the ESS and RES (the black line). C M I L P i is the energy cost of the day i achieved using the MILP solver at the end of the day (the red line). C s t r a t e g y i is the energy cost of the day i achieved by applying our strategy. Fig. 14 shows the effectiveness of each strategy for the three different homes in February 2014. As shown in this figure, for a stable home, the MILP-based supervised learning strategy saves approximately 82.8% of the average energy cost saved by the MILP solver; the average cost savings achieved by the MADDPG-based strategy and forecast-based strategy are only 74% and 48.3%, respectively. For fluctuating and chaotic homes, the average cost saved by the MILP-based supervised learning is also higher than those of other strategies. These results confirm that the performances of the MILP-based supervised learning and forecast-based strategies are the best and worst, respectively, among the three proposed strategies. These results are attributable to the fact that, in this study, the DNNs of the MILP-based supervised learning approximated MILP optimization better than those of the MADDPG-based strategy; on the other hand, the errors of the 24 -hour predictions of energy consumption, GHI, and real-time prices worsen the performance of the forecast-based strategy. The effectiveness of three strategies is also illustrated by RES energy loss metric calculated as in (9). As depicted in Fig. 15, the loss of the RES energy under the MILP-based supervised learning strategy is the least while this loss under the forecast-based MILP strategy is the most in the three kinds of homes. Furthermore, on average, the forecast-based strategy saves more energy cost for a fluctuating home than other homes because the hourly energy consumed for a fluctuating home is the highest. When the control of the ESS and RES is degraded in the forecast-based strategy, the performance of this strategy for a fluctuating home is improved by absorbing significant RES energy. As shown in Fig. 15, the loss of the RES energy in the fluctuating home is the least among the three kinds of home. 4.3 ESS status under three strategies To gain better insights into the performance of three strategies, the changing of ESS status under three strategies in the stable home during a day is shown in Figs. 16, 17, and 18. As shown in these figures, in the stable home, the hourly energy consumption of the appliances is small and stable during a day. Generally, three strategies in this home buy and charge cheap energy from the electricity provider to ESS at the low-price time slots and discharge it for appliances and selling at the high-price time slots. However, our proposed strategy utilizes cheap energy from the electricity provider and RES energy better than two remaining strategies. As shown in Fig. 16, at low-price time slots from 1 to 7 , our proposed strategy maximally buys and stores cheap energy from the electricity provider to ESS. Moreover, when RES energy is higher than the energy consumption of all appliances at time slots from 10 to 16 , ESS under our proposed strategy is turned to the charging mode and all exceeded RES energy is stored to ESS for future use. However, as shown Fig. 17, at low-price time slots 6 and 7 , the amount of cheap energy stored to ESS under the MADDPG-based strategy is not maximum. Moreover, at times slots 10 and 11 , ESS under the MADDPG-based strategy is turned to the discharging mode and some exceeded RES energy is lost. These results make the performance of the MADDPG-based strategy is worse than that of our proposed strategy. Under the forecast-based MILP strategy, at time slots 10 to 16 , ESS is turned to the discharging mode and a lot of exceeded RES energy is lost. This makes the loss of RES energy under the forecast-based MILP strategy the largest among three strategies and thus the performance of this strategy is the worst among three strategies in the stable home. Figs. 19, 20, and 21 show the changing of ESS status under three strategies in the fluctuating home. In this home, the hourly energy consumption of appliances is very high and fluctuating during a day. It is worth noting that at all time slots, the hourly energy consumption always higher than RES energy generated by PV systems. Hence, the loss of RES energy under three strategies is almost zero even though the control of ESS and RES is degraded. In the same way as they control ESS and RES in the stable home, these strategies still try to buy and store cheap energy from the electricity provider at the low-price time slots and use it for appliances and selling at the high-price time slots. However, the performance of our proposed strategy is still better than that of other strategies in this home. As shown in Fig. 19, at these low-price time slots from 1 to 7 , our proposed strategy maximally buys and stores cheap energy from the electricity provider to ESS and this energy is discharged for appliances and sold at high-price time slots such as 9 , 11 , 12 , 13 , and 20 . However, as shown in Fig. 20, at low-price time slots from 1 to 3 , the amount of energy charged to ESS under the MADDPG-based strategy is very small and this strategy also sells very small energy at high-price time slots such as 13 and 20 while it sells a lot of energy at low-price time slot 8 . Likewise, the forecast-based MILP strategy stores small energy at low-price time slots from 1 to 3 and it does not sell energy at high-price time slots 9 , 11 , 12 , and 13 at all. Moreover, this strategy buys and stores a lot of energy at high-price time slot 9 and 10 . These results make the forecast-based MILP strategy the worst among three strategies. Figs. 22, 23, and 24 show the changing of ESS status under three strategies in the chaotic home. In this home, the hourly energy consumption of appliances is really chaotic and very difficult to predict. In general, three strategies try to control ESS and RES in the similar way they do in the stable and fluctuating homes. In other words, they try to buy and store cheap energy from the electricity provider at the low-price time slots and sell them at the high-price time slots. Although the accuracy of controlling ESS and RES under all three strategies is very low, the performance of our proposed strategy is the best and that of the forecast-based MILP strategy is the worst among three strategies. As shown in Fig. 23, the amount of energy stored to ESS at the low-price time slots 6 , 7 , and 8 under the MADDPG-based strategy is not maximum. Moreover, this strategy also buys and stores energy from the electricity provider at the high-price time slots 13 and 14 and sells it at the low-price time slots 19 and 20 . These results degrade the performance of the MADDPG-based strategy. Under the forecast-based MILP strategy, the big errors of the 24-hours predictions of energy consumption, GHI, and real-time prices worsen the control of ESS and RES. As shown in Fig. 24, the forecast-based MILP strategy only buys and stores cheap energy from the electricity provider at time slot 1 and uses it at time slot 9 . In summary, the control of ESS and RES under the MILP-based supervised learning strategy is the best and the loss of RES energy under this strategy is the smallest among three strategies in all three kinds of homes. On the other hand, the control of ESS and RES under the forecast-based strategy is the worst and the loss of RES energy under this strategy is the largest among three strategies in three kinds of homes. These makes the MILP-based supervised learning strategy and the forecast-based strategy the best and the worst, respectively. 4.4 Computational time of two hour-ahead strategies Table 2 shows the average computational time of the MILP-based supervised learning and MADDPG-based strategies in each time slot. As shown in this table, the computational time of the MILP-based supervised learning is more than that of the MADDPG-based strategy because, for prediction, supervised learning requires more DNNs than the MADDPG-based strategy in each time slot. Moreover, the DNNs of the supervised learning are built using Keras, a high-level deep learning API of Tensorflow, unlike the agents of the MADDPG-based strategy that are implemented using the low-level APIs of Pytorch. However, the computational time of these strategies is very small. In this table, the computational time of the forecast-based strategy is not shown or included in the comparative evaluation because the strategy is a day-ahead strategy, unlike the other two, which are hour-ahead. 5 Discussion Unlike typical traditional methods, the proposed MILP-based supervised learning does not interfere with home appliances; rather, it unobtrusively minimizes the daily energy cost. Thus, it enables residents to maintain their appliance usage behavior and affords maximum comfort. However, as shown in Fig. 14, the performances of the proposed strategies decrease steadily when the resident behavior becomes increasingly chaotic. To apply our strategy to smart homes or buildings, residents should have a good appliance usage behavior, or the MAPE of the energy consumption prediction for the next 1 hour should be smaller than 21.8%. Although the forecast-based strategy, which is a day-ahead strategy, is the worst among the proposed strategies, it is not totally non-beneficial. Therefore, the hour-ahead and day-ahead strategies should be combined in smart houses. Day-ahead strategies enable residents to determine energy demand and easily participate in energy markets. On the other hand, hour-ahead strategies improve the performance of the HEMS and guarantee maximum lifestyle comfort. Moreover, the running time of the proposed strategies is insignificant, implying that it is very efficient when integrated with the coordinated DR of multiple HEMSs. 6 Conclusion We proposed an MILP-based supervised learning strategy for the hour-ahead DR of a HEMS that learned residents’ appliance usage behavior and applied the knowledge to minimize the daily energy cost. The DNNs of this strategy were trained using datasets created by an MILP solver with historical data to approximate the MILP optimization. After training, in each time slot, these DNNs were used to control the ESS and RES using the current real-time environmental information. The strategy was also compared to the MADDPG-based hour-ahead strategy and forecast-based day-ahead strategy. Three different case studies were conducted based on the residents’ appliance usage behavior. The case study results demonstrated the effectiveness of the MILP-based supervised learning, in terms of the daily energy cost. The average cost saved by this strategy was up to 73.8% of the average cost saved by the MILP solver for a home in which the MAPE of the 1 -hour prediction was only 21.8%. Across all case studies, the strategy was also the best strategy. Future works will aim at developing a cooperative strategy for groups of homes where a resident in each home will buy or sell energy. This strategy will be achieved by extending the proposed strategy. Basically, our MILP-based supervised learning strategy can be considered as an MILP-based IL strategy in which our DR attempted to mimic the MILP solver using the supervised learning technique, a traditional approach of the IL. Hence, another way to improve the proposed strategy is to apply advanced IL algorithms such as DAgger [33]. We also plan to include more penalty costs such as ESS degradation cost for our future work. coredata.dc:description: The demand response (DR) program of a traditional home energy management system (HEMS) usually controls or schedules appliances to monitor energy usage, minimize energy cost, and maximize user comfort. In this study, instead of interfering with appliances and changing residents’ behavior, the proposed hour-ahead DR strategy first learns the appliance usage behavior of residents; subsequently, based on this knowledge, it silently controls the energy storage system (ESS) and renewable energy system (RES) to minimize the daily energy cost. To accomplish the goal, the proposed deep neural networks (DNNs) of this DR approximate the MILP optimization using supervised learning. The training datasets are created from the optimal outputs of an MILP solver using historical data. After training, in each time slot, these DNNs are used to control the ESS and RES using the real-time data of the surrounding environment. For comparison, we develop two different strategies, namely, the multi-agent reinforcement learning-based strategy, which is an hour-ahead strategy, and the forecast-based MILP strategy, which is a day-ahead strategy. For evaluation and verification, the proposed approaches are applied to three different real-world homes with real-world real-time global horizontal irradiation and prices. Numerical results verify the effectiveness and superiority of the proposed MILP-based supervised learning strategy, in terms of the daily energy cost.
